I was beginning to think that the MGM just did not want me to drink or gamble and I should just go to bed. The next morning we had an early and long day so I decided to order room service. This is something I have done hundreds of times but the sticker shock this time was enough to say I would never stay at the MGM again. I ordered two bagels with cream cheese, two coffees, two bottles of water and a bowl of sliced fruit. The total came to $92.00!!!! Then when I asked her to charge it to the room another thing I have dome a million times and was told I had to pay for it upfront which to avoid any further delay I did. The gentleman that brought the tray was very nice and the food was as exciting as bagels get but for sure not worth the $92.00. The third night we centered on going to the Hakkassan club to see DJ Tiesto. This is where I say I have 10 years as a nightclub manager in a major city and 10 years as a Catering Manager for a popular hotel chain. Nothing kills me then a poorly thought out nightclub. There was hundreds of people in line but being used to Vegas I bought pre-sale tickets. We got in pretty fast. But then came the 5 flights of stairs to get to the first dance floor area. It screamed fire hazard. A further set of stairs led you to a main room, which is where Tiesto was supposed to play. The lay out was 70% VIP Booths 3% Bar (as far as I could see) and the most cramped dance floor I have ever seen (as of that moment). We stayed for about 10 minutes before we decided to go find a drink, which did not happen since we were corralled back into a hallway that led to a stairwell. We decided to take the stairwell to the hip hop room which had a dance floor the size of a condo living room and at least a hundred people trying to dance. We danced for about 10 more minutes, still needing a drink but with  no bar in sight, we left. Again this room was about 70% VIP booths.  It was almost 1am and I would say 80% of those booths were empty. We braved the 5 flights of stairs out of this potential towering inferno and went to the Lobby Bar. At this point, I just wanted to drink and saw the $70 Tiesto tickets as a wash. We arrived at the Lobby Bar to what looked like 4 waitresses huddled at other the end of the bar. Waited......Waited.... And then just went up to the bar. Drinks were good but at this point we just called it a night. One bright note is that I dropped my phone and Lost and Found had it. The breakfast buffet was eh. We ate at Hecho in Vegas which was pretty good. The pool areas were nice and the whole casino in very clean. I just feel like the gold standard is gone and could pay less to get the same at another casino. FYI New York New York had the best Irish Bar ever. Maybe I will stay there next time so I can drink and gamble on my schedule not the wait staff's.

Recently spent 2 nights in one of the Terrace Suites. It was my 30th b-day so I and my wife went all out.

The terrace with the hot tub was awesome. Nookie action in the outdoor hot tub overlooking the strip made the cost of this room worth it. Also the bed and pillows were super comfortable. The view from the bed was also awesome.

HOWEVER...the little things wrong at MGM amounted this room to only 3 stars.

And the biggest thing that peeved us was THE HALLWAY WAS FILTHY!!!!! We showed up at the room and next to our door were two empty glasses and one of those plastic ice buckets you get at the pool with empty beer cans it. Across the hall were tables and chair stacked up being stored in the hallway. Also across the hall were a bunch of dirty dishes laying on the floor from someone's roomservice. All of this stuff (except the two glasses, which were there for the duration of our stay) were removed the second day of our stay.

Here is a list of the smaller problems.

1. MGM has done a terrible job of maintaining the rooms. The handle on the glass sliding door was super loose and felt like it was about to come off. I had to tighten the screws with my thumb.
2. Two of the over head lights in front of the 2 story windows were  blown out...one was just completely busted out.
3. No soap dish in the shower...you had to set your stuff on the ground when switching between soap and shampoo.
4. NO ELECTRONIC EXPRESS CHECKOUT ON THE TV. You had drop a card with you room info in the elevator lobby and examine you final bill at a later date.
5. TV in bathroom was broken
6. Maid service did not empty all of teh garbage cans

For a $1000 a night room, these problems are totally unacceptable. This easily could have been a 5 star stay except for these little things that amounted to allot.

As far as the casino goes, it was packed during the day, but died down earlier than other more hip hotels, I guess because it was more of a family place. Cocktail service while in the machines sucked, but was pretty good while we were at the tables. Dining options were probably the best of any of the hotels I stayed at. Options ranged all the way from McDonald's to some 5 star french place and everything else in between. The pool area was average, and was a long walk from the hotel. THE LAZY RIVER WAS CLOSED!!!

This place holds a lot of events and we enjoyed the luxury huge reception halls that they have.
   This is a wonderful place and always packed with people....but you do have to do a lot of footwork to get where you have to go...
    I like to go on the tours of Grand Canyon...etc...

Our stay here was okay. We ordered a double queen suite, but somehow got a regular double queen room instead. That really sucked and there was nothing they can do about it. 
Our bedsheets had either blood or feces stains on it, I was so disgusted and just ripped off that sheet. I was too tired to complain even more to the front desk people and disappointed already from our room.
The shower took some time to get hot water at night time. 
Our mini fridge was missing a beverage before we got in our room, but when we checked out we informed them that so they wouldn't charge us. 
We stayed on the floor that didn't allow smoking and had better air flow, minerals in our shower or something like that lol, "stay well" floor.

We went to the pool party, wet republic, downstairs one day and my BF stepped on glass out there, there's not supposed to be any glass out there and it's pretty serious for him cuz he's a diabetic. They got him cleaned up, but it kind of hurt his foot all day. 
The night club Hakkasan was alright, we went on a Friday night and the crowd there was ehhh. I encountered a lot of rude drunk people that I tried my best not to fight lol. $20 for a glass of lemon vodka. I should have brought my flask since they didn't check the girls' purses. It was pretty crowded, but there's different floors too. 

Overall, the hotel was nice. It's in a good location on the strip. I'll probably try a different hotel next time I go.
rainforest cafe!! they were undercontruction i didn't even want to enter it fear of somethin falling on me.

Check-in was fast and simple, and the girl behind the counter was funny and cute. Everything in the casino is very convenient for those staying at the hotel, and there aren't any long walks to get to different services or amenities. 

The room itself was okay. My bed was very comfortable, and I like the automatic double curtains. The bathroom seemed a bit run down, however.

Not the most exciting hotel. The staff isn't the most pleasant either. Props to the housekeepers that's the only thing this place got right. 

Side note: room service coffee $24
Classic hotel with great name recognition. The hotel is very clean, the staff is friendly and the place is organized. Vegas is busy and all of the great hotels have busy check in lines. Be prepared.

Guess what! We checked into our room and found a DIRTY TOWEL inside the shower and a dirty pillow case. Called guest services and room service has NOT showed up. And they refuse to move us to another room. Customer service at its best guys. Avoid at all cost

The MGM is a great place to stay if you're the type of person who likes to spend a lot of time in the casino where you're staying. The hotel itself is decent. The casino, food, entertainment options at the MGM is vast, so you can spend a lot if tune here and not be bored, but for my liking, its too far away from everything else. Not really anything negative to say about the place, but its also definitely not top on my list of Vegas spots to stay.

Went here for the Mayweather VS Marquez fight. I ordered a fight package through the hotel that included $75 credit to any restaurant and a add $75 credit to the spa which I never used. As soon as a walked in I was in awe the lobby was very spacious and elegant. This was the biggest hotel I ever stayed at, it took me 10 minuets to walk from my room to the arena. They have like 4 pools one of them being a club(Wet Republic) which was an amazing experience. This was my first trip to Vegas and will have to compare hotels to this one. But definably would say here again and would not be disappointed.

There are TONS of shops and restaurants throughout the property. They have a wide variety of options from high class expensive restaurants and shops to basics fast food like McDonald's. The casino is lively and clean.

Average priced but if you book wayyy in advance for the pre-season Kings game like I do, its a great hotel.  Nothing beats rolling out of your prepartying minutes before and going straight into the game or meeting up with friends.

Regular room: Great for 2 beds, bathroom has a lock and its spacious enough that 2-3 ppl can throw their stuff around and not step on each other's toes.  No fridge one time & the other time had a weighted fridge that charges you if you move anything more than 2 secs.  :(

Regular Suite:  King bed w\/ lots of room around to move.  Gigantic tub that you can swim in and a spacious bathroom to boot.  The living room is great for having a group of ppl over to preparty but the couches aren't comfy enough to crash on.  Comes with a mini fridge that is empty and you can put drinks in.  Yeah!

West Wing Reg room: Nice layout, very modern and chic.  Fits a king bed but its not as spacious as their regular rooms.  There is no bathroom lock...just frosted glass on the shower \/ toilet.  Great for couples or single folks, not so much if you don't know the ones you're sharing the room with.  No fridge.

If anything goes amuck, be sure to square your customer service issues IN PERSON.  I emailed and they said they would help me out on a room but never got back to me.  When you're part of a company that owns more than half the casinos on the strip, dealing with 1 irrate customer is not a big deal.  Do it in person...and you'll get it taken care of.

Horrible experience while checking in today. First, They put me in a room that wasn't cleaned and then switched me over to a room where keys were not working. Asking me to wait until security comes in and opens the door for me. Too much for a Grand Luxury experience. Sucks! Never staying again at this horrible place. Aria was way way better.

I can't speak to the hotel accommodations but there is an air of excitement at the MGM Grand that his hard to replicate at any of the other hotels on the strip.  Despite having been around for a long time, the MGM Grand constantly remakes itself so that even today it is a modern and luxurious facility.  There are plenty of shops, eateries, and gambling space to keep you occupied for hours.  

David Copperfield plays here and KA the Cirque du Soleil show with martial arts bent is housed here.  

I suspect because it's been around so long that the hotel is not as nice as the newer ones on the strip - Bellagio, Cosmopolitan, Aria, Mandarin Oriental, etc... but although I might not want to stay here, it is a fun place to hang out and gamble.

Upon arrival,  this place is was impressive.  Probably largest hotel on the strip.  Took us about 30 minutes to checkin due to the March madness crowd.  Glad we were able to check in early without getting charged the extra fee as a result of being a M-Life member (free to anyone to apply).  Resort has a tremendous amount of restaurants, which includes a food court which is nice. Easy to get lost in the enormous place, but we're glad we stayed here and would gladly visit again.

First time staying here and got some awesome rates for the Yelp Spring Break Weekend!! 
We got HOOKED up with 2 bottles of champagne and an upgraded room. 
Enjoyed the eateries in the hotel and the pool area is HUGE with Wet Republic as well as 5 other areas to tan, drink, and relax.
Service we received was very good, I would definitely come back.

MGM did a few things right... Their check in line was not a cluster of chaos, their customer service was great, the shows\/bars\/casino was on point, the hotel itself is grand. However, we booked on a hotel app with no pictures and went for the best deal... Our room: not great, could hear every noise from passer byers or the people next door, it was dated, maintenance could really try to spruce things up or fix light bulbs that are out... but, you get what you pay for. I tried to save money and failed. I give it 4 stars because it was a great experience, great location, and not too crowded during the Super Bowl... Next time I know better then to save a few bucks with a hotel app.

I know, people go to Vegas to gamble, kick game, dance, drink, get some action, see some skin and\/or to eat at the buffets. (Did I ever tell you that I can eat my money back in bacon? It's true, don't try to challenge me. But that's another entry.) I'm amazed by the millions of dollars poured into Las Vegas to make it what it is and respect the entrepreneurs who are just trying to get theirs. But it's not my kind of town. I like the beaches, laid back attitudes and slow pace of the tropics.
And then I was convinced by a friend to check out the MGM Grand Spa.
Oh me, oh my, my senses were met with the scent of lavender and eucalyptus. Coming from the casinos smelling of cig butt, the spa entrance was like heaven. I must have looked like I was experiencing euphoria because my friend seemed thrilled that I was loving some part of Vegas. Mind you, we were just in the front entrance.
They suggested I try a hot stone massage, promising it would be good one. We asked the spa receptionists if there were any openings for later  in the afternoon. Fate on my side, they said yes and would we be interested in checking in now? Shoot, if I was smitten with the entrance, I could only imagine what heavenly goodness was past those doors. Heck ya, check my a$$ in. We walked in an hour and a half before our appointments and were anxious to be pampered.
People, this spa was GORGEOUS. It is what every spa should look like or attempt to be. No longer will I go to a spa that lacks a lounge area. MGM Grand Spa had hot and warm pools, a TV area and a quiet area with comfy cushy chaise longues. Fruit, snacks, water, coffee and tea were also provided. We wrapped ourselves in luxuriously thick robes and dangled our legs in the hot tub. We weren't prepared with our bathing suits so we had to improvise. Ten minutes before our treatments, we went to the quiet area and relax. I was ready to nap when my massage therapist called my name.
Her name was Marla. I can't nor will I try to explain the wonders of her stone massage. Of all the massages I've ever had, hers was the best. Ever. I was ready to propose to her when she was done and I'm completely in love with my boyfriend. She led me back to the lounge area and gave me a hug goodbye. As I exited this heavenly oasis, I signed my credit card bill with no regrets.  
Please, do yourself a favor. If you are ever in Las Vegas and need a little lovin', don't bother grinding at a club, going to a skin show or entertaining a one night stand. Or do. Who am I to tell you how to get your swerve on? :) But you also got to see Marla. She will make you feel like a million bucks. And you won't go home dirty*.
When I got back from my trip, I told my boyfriend about my spa experience but didn't go into much detail. Our conversation went like this- 
Me: "I went to a spa." 
The Man: "Didn't you just do that?!" 
Me: I threw my arms around him, kissed him, and confessed, "It's like crack! I'm addicted!"
The Man: "I think crack is cheaper.

I'm gonna be honest, I love the MGM but there's a huge problem with the monorail entrance in the studio walk, no proper signs to it. The one place where they really need the sign to point you to the monorail is just an overhead sign that says "Wet Republic" how much do they pay you to have it up there? I get the same question every other person "where is the monorail?" Well by then they've already passed it.... its right next to Diego restaurant.... Lol. I digress. The hotel and casino are nice I must admit. The rooms are getting revamped (or so I hear) and the music is fantastic walking through the vast halls. The parking garage is never full (i use guest parking that way I'm closer to Tropicana, the street) and the starlane shops are great! I especially love the magic shop. The employees are fantastic. When I came in as a guest they were helpful and great, and now I work here. The security does their job amazingly. The pool is huge and always busy (even in November) I recommend it. It's not the Ritzy high class place some people want to see, but its worth its price. I do however say if you are staying do stock up from a store on Tropicana, as a local, I cringe at some of the prices of things! $3 20 oz coke is too much! Especially if I can get it for $1.49 at Walmart. 
Oh! And just FYI, in the MGM you will see a lot of stars. I met Ryan Styles here. Drew Carrey and the crew are around often as well as Colin Furgesson and I've heard tell members of old 80s hair bands come here. XD MGM Grand definitely has nostalgia to it, keep that in mind.
EDIT: Lions are gone :( Grrrr

Oh where do I begin:  The carpets throughout the room areas are absolutely filthy. The room updates are not functional: the bathroom has no actual door (hence no privacy of sound whatsoever), the door of the toilet is of reflective glass so you can watch yourself do your business, the  shower has no place to hang\/reach your dry towel, the light for the bathroom area shines a beam into the whole room.  The desk lamp gives a glow, but very little light.  The concierge couldn't even provide a breakfast restaurant suggestion other than "We have a buffet." When asked if there was a hot tub on site, the front desk said to "try our spa for a fee of $25" when there actually was an accessible hot tub in the pool area .

We will  NOT be back.

I must say, a nice hotel, Impressed how nice our room was, and we got the room for a steal for the 5 nights we were there. It took awhile to check in\/ out, and that kinda sucked, but its always busy in Vegas, and when the guy in front of you has 20 questions..well...
.Our room was at the very end of the hall, before the Skylofts, so heels came off and we walked barefoot till we got to the elevator. A girls gotta do what a girls gotta do... I would stay again.

Despite their planned "grand renovation", the service here stinks. I have been coming to MGM regularly for the last 9 years and this last visit will be my last as they have  worsened each time.

With new properties abound, MGM is an artifact resting on its branding from decades ago. A facelift isn't going to fix it. New approaches to treating guests are desperately needed. I had to switch rooms due to water being cut off for 8-hour periods(!), the generic cafe-restaurant closes at 11PM (we are in Vegas, people--24 hours is a must), and being transferred by phone 3 times to answer a simple question about "MLife" is simply not acceptable. Why bother with their loyalty progam? I won't be back.

I've stayed at this hotel twice and both times found the rooms clean and the staff very accommodating. On the most recent visit, we booked a room in the west wing because they were advertised as quieter and more modern. However, we found the room to be a little too small and less luxurious than the rooms in the main part of the hotel.  Plus the west wing  is a long walk from the more interesting parts of the casino. So I would recommend staying in the main part of the hotel if possible.

Beware of unlisted drink prices! $22 for two well vodka-tonics - Yikes!

I've been coming to MGM many years but extremely very disappointed that they now charge for parking....really?  Ever since MGM opened parking was always free.  I guess MGM doesn't want my business any more...I suggest going to South Point at least their parking is completely free..

Are you kidding me? Okay I get it. Nothing in life is free but hey you figure if you stay at the hotel self parking in the MGM Hotel it should be free. Nope not free. SMH pretty disappointing. Room 10-536

We stayed here for the weekend. At check-in Christian was great, very welcoming. We up graded to what we thought was a better room with a strip view, but for the extra money we expected more from the room ( bigger, actual strip view). But it served its purpose, and we still had a good time.

Waited 2 hours at check in line from 1:30am to 3:30am.

Got a reservation but the rooms are not cleaned.

50 angry customer waiting for clean room at 3:30am

I will go to a casino a couple of times a year with my boyfriend and we decided to go to the MGM in Vegas a week ago. The hotel was huge with plenty of slots and tables.  The food was pretty good but could be better. You can certainly get any cuisine you want. If not, the hotel is right on the strip so you can get to other casinos ant restaurants really easy.  The only bad thing is that I think we must have had some spring breakers there because it could get a little more wild than I like at a casino. Went out to the clubs once and had fun but was expensive.

ithink MGM Grand is the only property in Vegas that might very well appeal to everyone....college kids on spring break, families, high rollers, and people on a modest budget all can enjoy themselves here. The place is HUGE, there is a LOT to do, a great selection of restaurants that touch on a variety of cuisines, including the great Joel Robuchon's namesake restaurant (a must do on my honeyroom stopover in Sept.). If you signup online or text them you can get pretty good deals on rooms (which are nothing special but get the job done and are clean and comfy). If you are going to Vegas for the first time, I recommend MGM. Then try Bellagio or mandalay next time. Oh by the way, get a players card and gamble and stay ONLY at MGM MIrage-affiliated casinos (there's like eight of them on the strip  I think). You can reap some incredible rewards..I just got two nights free at Mandalay Bay...so I'll be writing that review when I get back.

MGM is definately a favorite. Have been upgraded numerous times to "nice" rooms. Their rooms are very comfortable but a little dated. i understand they are getting ready for a renovation. The skyloft rooms are great if you are looking for a treat.

Their dealers are sometimes a little stoic but i have won there more than lost so really not an issue. cocktails do not seem to be a problem and i think they have the last remaining mechanical horse race game in the world. imagine 10 people (all seats filled) betting on little plastic horses clumping a round a little track yelling so loud people from the craps tables come over to see what all the fun is. hard to discribe.
Walking through the endless hallways after the Hatton fight was a Fear and Loathing-esque nightmare odyssey.

I thought it was kinda cool that someone responded to the numerous negative comments. Sadly, went to dinner and a concert there (I won't stay or gamble there again), and nothing had changed. Talked to a few guests who had been ambushed by the valet and resort fees that had driven me away. No point apologizing if you don't make improvements. M Life is definitely not the life for me!

ONLY READ IF YOU CARE ABOUT CUSTOMER SERVICE WHEN COMING TO VEGAS WITH KIDS AND TO ENJOY OF A FAMILY ORIENTED EXPERIENCE. 

I have visited Vegas numerous times before, and I wanted to stay at a better place such as the Aria or the Palazzo, but my brother (based on advertisement) paid a lot and decided to celebrate my sister-in-law's birthday at the MGM "GRAND" (I wasn't really up for it but my family came from abroad and this is their first time here) she is six month pregnant and with a 2 years old baby. We are focussing our visit mostly for the museums, buffets and family shows. 
We arrived from L.A. really tired (having a 2 years old in the car for 5 hours, I guess you get the picture), I was hoping for an easy and welcoming check-in process but instead after waiting in line for around an hour, a new employee at the front desk gave us our rooms for the 25th floor, we went there but our keys didn't work and we had to figure out for ourselves that out rooms where actually on the 24th floor; once there, my brother, his pregnant wife and my asmathic 2 years old niece went to their (non-smoking) room that reeked to cigarettes, so I called to the front desk to ask for an accommodation and they gave us a different room in the same floor with "a view" (they charged us $25 extra a night per room for a strip view) facing the Mandala Bay Hotel (needless to say how awkward that was, besides there're no other big hotels on that "view"). We went down to the lobby trying to ask for a better accommodation. Finally, after a two and a half hours check-in process and ask 5 times to be to talk to a manager, Catherine (the manager) came to "help us", she was super defensive and not willing to emphasize with how uncomfortable for us all this had been so far, she actually offered set up a machine to extract the oddors out of the original room or move us again to another floor. Considering my little niece's well being we decided to take our party to a lower floor and end with all this so we could relax. After two and a half our in, "celebrating" my pregnant sister-in-law's birthday and all the hassle we went through, our "more than generous compensation" (described this way by Catherine) was to refund  to us 3 of the 6 resort fees charged. I know that any other place would have cared more about our "experience". 
Anyhow, it is up to you to decide whether you want to choose this place or not to enjoy with your family, I know for a fact that hospitality in Vegas can do way better than this. I won't stay here ever again and I won't recommend it either.

The MGM really seems to be a mixed bag.

The pluses:
- There is lots to do and see.  Plenty of different places to eat and different entertainment options available for all tastes.
- Overall the room in the West Wing (steerage) was fine.  The only problems were in the bathroom, which will be detailed below.

The minuses:
- $30 mandatory "resort fee", for services we didn't need.  We were told we could not opt out.  considering we had to pay for it, both my wife and I tried to connect to the WiFi.  We tried several times .. never were able to connect.  I'm a techie, so I'm certan the problem was not on our end.
- The television was intermittent.  The signal would come and go.  We tried to use the check out option through the television before we left ... it was unavailable (got an error code)
- The hot water was intermittent in the shower .. fine at the sink.  There was something wrong with the mixer in the shower.  Switching from the showerhead to the handheld nozzle resulted in an extremely loud screeching noise from the pipes.
-The climate control is located in the nightstand on one side of the bed, so when the fan comes on, all the air and NOISE is in the ear of the person on that side of the bed.  This wasn't a huge deal if you sleep near the center of the king bed.
-Everything associated with the hotel is overpriced.

At this point I would have given the MGM three stars.

The worst::
Got food poisoning from one of the restaurants in the food court.  Called MGM about it and was transferred to security.  Security wasn't interested in hearing about it because it occurred at a vendor restaurant.  The security officer told me to call the restaurant, which of course I was going to do anyway.  Now, I understand that the restaurant isn't owned by the MGM, however I think that the MGM would want to know about, and monitor, a vendor who's food was making an MGM guest sick.   A quick web search revealed that this restaurant, which serves hot dogs, has made others sick.

The shortcomings in the room and the resort fee are what they are.  But blowing off a guest who was made sick by a restaurant in your facility is a deal breaker for me.

So big, I tend to forget about MGM because it is on the boring end of the Strip. But, if you are a tourist check it out. Always the home of the big events. It does feel a little older when you compare to all the new things and the Sportsbook needs a major overhaul.

B room*** 2 1\/2 stars on the place to poo scale. Not super clean and feels more like a food court bathroom.***

Even though MGM is considered one of the older hotels on the strip, its interior has been kept up quite nicely.  The lobby and the casino are HUGE and well-decorated -- one of my friends actually got lost in the casino when we first arrived and it took us 15 minutes to regroup.

Anyhow, my friends and I stayed here over Halloween weekend and we got a steal on the rooms -- we're poor grad students (read low-rollers) so we had zero chance of a comp.  We booked a regular grand tower room at ~$200 total and a bungalow queen suite for ~$240 total, which was a great deal during the popular weekend.  Customer service was extremely attentive and friendly, and did not charge us extra for additional room keys.

The rooms were not overly luxurious, but did have a quality feel and furnishings well-kept even though they might be somewhat old.  The tube TVs were a bit out-dated I must say, but who goes to Vegas to watch TV?  Seriously.  The regular grand tower room is pretty comparable in size to rooms in any of the other hotels on the strip.  The bungalow queen suite included a nice spacious sitting area with a second TV, coffee table, lounge chair, and sofa (big enough for someone to sleep on actually).  The beds were just heavenly.  The only negative thing I could probably say about this place is that the walls are pretty thin.  We could hear our crazy neighbors partying hard again at 8 am the next morning!

Overall, MGM has a fairly younger crowd with great amenities, customer service, comfort, location, and rates.  This hotel is probably one of the best all-around on the strip.

So it doesn't seem like we are just trashing this place, we have stayed here several times before and were excited to return this time.

Today we arrived at MGM at 7:10 pm. We were directed to agent Alejandro who advised we could upgrade our room to a bigger one for $150 more per night. We declined but thanked him for the offer. He then informed us our room (a grand king premier view) was not ready, but that we could have a similar room with 2 queen beds. Queen beds were not what we made a reservation for and not what we wanted. The agent then stepped away for about 15 mins and came back to tell us he could give us 2 buffets and we could wait 1-2 hours for our original room with a king bed. We had our dinner with us, which we were hoping to enjoy in our room after a day of traveling, so we really had no need for comp buffets. We were given room keys, filled out an info card with email and phone number and were told we would receive a call when the room was ready. We sat in the food court for 2 hours, ate our dinner and waited. No call came. We went back to the front desk and was told our room was ready, totally nonchalantly, like we hadn't been waiting for anything. The agent said they don't make phone calls about rooms being ready after 6pm, that department was closed. We asked to speak to a manager. 

She apologized, said Alejandro was new and they would talk to him, sorry we didn't get a phone call, he is a new agent and they did give us 2 buffets and our room had been upgraded to one with a view. 
Whether a guest gets a call or not is a pretty general info type of thing. If he disappeared to the back for 15 mins, perhaps a manager should have accompanied him back to the front to make sure he gave us the right info. Thank you manager for saying you'll talk to him about this issue, but let's be serious, that helps your hotel in its future interactions with guests, that does nothing to compensate for our inconvenience or make us feel valued as customers. As for our room with a view, that was exactly what our reservation was for, maybe you could review our record before assuming you had done us a favor. 9:50 pm we finally got to sit in our room. At this point we're just so disappointed, not excited to spend money at this hotel or ever return again. 
*It took much restraint not to litter this review with curse words.

For the most part we had a pleasant stay here for my birthday. Stayed here on October 9th.

We got to the hotel around 4pm on a Sunday. Wasn't rushing for the 3pm check in, just to give the lines a chance to die down a bit. Boy was I wrong about that! We should've came sooner! The entire lobby was packed! Luckily, a nice lady redirected us to a separate & much shorter line. She noticed we had our toddler in a stroller and as she said, "saved 2 ours of our time" SO THANKFUL FOR HELPFUL CUSTOMER SERVICE! 

Check in was easy, service was great, & Justin even gave us a free upgrade. Our room was originally supposed to be 1 king bed, but instead we got 2 queens. He said it was a little bit bigger than the other room & I had no problem with that, since I read reviews that that room was small anyway. & it was a chance to see if our daughter wanted to sleep in her own bed lol. 

The room itself was clean, beds were comfortable, and had a fully stocked refrigerator. Don't touch the items inside, unless you plan on buying them because they do have a sensor! It's cool they have these options, but wish they didnt stuff them or left a little room for guests to store their own drinks or left over food. 

By the time we got up to the room, it was about 4:30, got changed and headed for the pool. Only to find out, they close at 5 :( 
So we went to go change and left to walk around the strip that night. Woke up early the next day to hit up the pool with the fam before checkout. Forgot to check the weather until we were halfway there and it was a little chilly! But the pool was a little heated and good enough for us to enjoy for a bit.

When we got back up to the room, the bathroom smelled like sewage. Not sure what caused it cause it wasn't like that they day\/night before. 

Overall, MGM is a good location, there is a lot to see and different attractions, like Top Golf or other hotels\/casinos that are easy to walk to. You won't be bored, & if you get tired you'll be in walking distance to take a nap. 

I liked that they also have a variety of fast food to chose from, when we didn't wanna opt for the buffet or more pricier restaurants.

I had read some reviews after booking and was a little scared about staying here, however I kept an open mind and walked through the doors ready to have a positive experience and boy did I! Check in was a breeze. Sure there was a line, but it moved quickly and efficiently! The lady that checked me in was soooo nice and soooo helpful! I believe her name was Kanesha or Nanesha and she was great! I asked for a room to see the strip and she very pleasantly granted me that request. She answered all of my questions and guided me to my room, which is in the grand tower and it is just right. I have a very nice view of the strip, the room is clean and modern, no noise from the hallway. It's a big hotel but really I am excited to spend the next three nights here. Everyone has been very friendly and helpful. Great location, happening casino, and great staff. Thank you mgm, for a great beginning to this trip!

I stay 3-4 times in Vegas a year.  

  Don't expect anything super exceptional here, but do expect to spend your extra cash.  I loved my 2 bedroom-south tower suite, but that was about it.  Valet is good, check in not too bad, express check out is great.  The cocktail waitress service is sketchy, (just not enough of them on the floor).  Sports book needs some personality.  And come on, only 1 drink ticket per $100 bet!  Most places will give you 2 for a $50.  The pool was good.  I had an issue with a 2 for 1 offer for KA (which I received as part of my stay offer).  After 15 minutes the best they said they could do was charge me for the most expensive tickets and then they would honor the 2-1... I laughed.  Nowhere in my offer did it say that.   (Just another example of how this place sucks the juice out of your wallet)   Box office sent me to M Life to see what they could do.  The rep (Jan) was rude and unaccommodating.  Kept telling me they only did 30% off while I tried to show her my 2-1 email on my phone, but of course she didn't want to read it.  She had me speak to someone on the phone who apologized and basically said NOPE.  Finally just had to walk away while Jan was still going on and on...Very scammish.  Stay away from Wolfgang Pucks (that's a WHOLE diff story!)  Tried the "real" fitness center but they wanted an extra $10 per day to use it, and that's on top of the dreaded $25 per night resort fee.  The "fake" fitness center was free but only had cardio equip.  Slots don't play or pay with you (as most of the MLife casinos).   As for stays, this place is a one and done for me.

Worst experience ever!  My buddy booked a two bedroom suite months in advance, after a ten hour drive we came to find out that the hotel gave away our reservation. They offered us a much smaller room and some money. I don't understand the need to make a reservation.  I will never say a good thing about this hotel again or consider staying in any of their hotels or affiliated hotels. They clearly don't care about their customers or have any honor in the way they do business.

We went to MGM for CSI experience with high expectation. Unfortunately we found out this was a complete crap. It's just a artificial crime scene, a few framed descriptions and computers. Oh man! I felt like my intelligence was insulted. Plus their price is $28 per person but it's only worth $8. We were so disappointed!

We checked in a room that was filthy so we left. Lost two nights but ended up at Cosmopolitan where we had a great time. This place is a disgrace. Avoid at all cost. It reeks of cigarette, the clientele is questionable and the staff miserable.

I just got back from the MGM for a mid week stay to visit an old friend from my middle school days.  It was good to see my friend, not so good to stay at the MGM.

The hotel is smokey and smelly in a stinky 'lets spray lots of perfume to cover up this smell' kind of way.
 My room was musty and moldy. 
The shower head sprayed the water out so damn hard I swear I got bruises. 
There wasn't a fan in the bathroom in my room, no night light in the room either and also no robe, which I was really sad about...I like to lounge around hotel rooms in a robe. 
The bed was super comfortable though, nice and gushy with soft cool sheets. 

The Grand Buffet was a horrible rip off.  Thankfully (for me) my friend paid, but for the $27 she paid for my meal I would have much rather eaten Mexican food at Diego and paid the difference in cost. The buffet food was awful...it was full of fatty oil, salty, and just down right nasty.  My friend loved the buffet,  so I guess it just depends on who's eating. 

The pool area is HUGE, it spans over 6 acres. I think there are six pools to choose from, but none of them are European which I prefer so that kinda bummed me out too. 

What especially did the whole pool experience in for me was the drunk guy that threw up in the pool -he should have been cut off as he was obviously shit faced, but instead the waitress kept serving him and his buddies, then he got sick... right in the pool. They had to shut it down at that point. 

So I guess what it comes down to is I'm spoiled. I like my night light, and my robe...I don't care for buffets or drunks puking next to me while I'm in the pool. The stay wasn't all bad but I don't think I will seek out the MGM for a future stay in Las Vegas.

In a nutshell, this place is pretty good as far as giant resort casinos go.  It is a long walk from parking to registration to room, but once we got checked in and settled, it was better.  The hotel (resort) has everything you need so in theory you could stay there the whole trip and feel like you had a great vacation.  It's in a good location and a quick walk to NYNY or even Excalibur to get on the tram to Mandalay.  It is within walking distance to several shops and quick bite (ie fast food) restaurants, which is nice when you're not trying to be too fancy.  
We mostly played poker, and it was a good time.  The staff and dealers were all very nice and both my husband and I did well, which makes it hard to critize, but I will anyway.  My biggest beef is that the "poker room" is not a room.  It's a roped off spot on the side of the casino.  I wish it felt like poker players were more valued, but it is what it is.  
Other than that, we had a great stay.  The cafe made a mean club sandwich, I mean it was loaded with bacon and the bread was toasted just right.  Perfect.

WOW...what a let down!!! We got to the hotel and pulled into the Valet to check in. The attendant asked if we were staying or playing so I says checking in. Dude says "That will b $18 a night to valet" and I was like WTF "U serious" he says "Yup". First off I was shocked, me & my family have been coming to Vegas for 15 plus years & stayed @ numerous hotels on the strip. And I get it it was an adjustment when the dreaded "Resort Fees" appeared and the increased steadily. ..fine I get it. But paying to stay when I am already paying to stay, smfh. So I says to the guys what r my options he says to.me u can self park for $10 a day...WTFx2. I park it myself and I still got to pay a 10 spot...what the hel* did I get into. So I park my own ride, smdh, and check in. The lady @ the counter was nice & when we asked about the "Parking Fee" she was like yeah oh uh huh yeah yup it $10. Plus the muther luving resort fee @ $34 a day. 

So we get the key and head to the room, I didn't know I was gonna have ro hire Louis and Clark to get to it. Finding the elevator was easy but had to walk a danged country mile to finally get to the room.

The room was...not $#!+. I guess they tried to make it look modern and up to date but believe they failed. The toilet\/shower area is all glass and closed in, rather small. The bedroom area is ok but for nearly $200 a night u would expect more and better. We have stayed @ Wynn, Aria, Luxor, Bellagio even TI and the rooms were bigger and they felt like u got what u paid for, here not as much. Hopefully the experience gets better.  If u r looking for value for ur money this joint ain't it. Not only to u pay to stay the night  but u will do that 2 more times. Once for the resort fee and the other to park. I don't know if this is a trend w\/ the other hotels or not but this is not a good way to do buisness.

Ps...if there is some B$ canned robo reply about guest service and making guest happy from the MGM PR department If u truly mean b it then make it right call me actions speak louder than words! I'll update if they do but won't hold my breath.
Over 2 hours to check in on a Sunday afternoon. And now you have to pay to park. Will not be staying here again. Unacceptable!

Stayed here from (3-28-17\/3-31-17) I must stay that I had an amazing stay. From check in to check out everything was perfect. Dervin(hopefully I spelled it right) at check in was super sweet even when I kept hitting him with questions.He went over everything. Ann at check out was super awesome and went over all my charges with me.Everyone was super friendly, I was a little scared because of some of the other reviews that I read but I'm happy that I stayed here.
The hotel is huge every day my friend and I discovered a different part of the hotel which actually made it even more fun. We had a room in the grand tower (21st floor room 328) which we was told was in there newer tower. The view was simply amazing, The room was kept clean on a daily bases.Room service was awesome as well and everything tasted amazing. I went to the lobby bar one night and the bar and the selection of music by the dj was awesome he definitely kept it going. I ordered a vodka and it was strong just how I like it. We has two vouchers for the buffet which we took advantage of for dinner, love the fact that the crab legs was already cut... Depending on what you picked food wise it was hit or miss, The pizza, spring roll and garlic was amazing.
The pool area is huge and they also have a lazy river. From our room it was a long walk to the pool but we didn't mind because we discovered even more restaurants.It's so hard to leave the hotel when they offer so much from food to clubs and everything else in between. For it being my first trip to Vegas I'm so happy that I stayed here and my next trip out I hope to have the same experience.

Spring break in Vegas?  Sure, why not.  Jr. Yelpers were less than enthused but we got in a couple of family-comedy\/magic shows to placate them. 
MGM has an impressive lobby with a huge golden lion statue in the middle.  Our check-in process went smoothly and the clerk, Mai, was really nice.  They have a special prima card you can purchase for $500 which allows you to use at MGM and their affliate hotels, restaurants.  It's a way to get you to spend all your dough at their facilities.  

Our rooms were nice, clean and the marbled art deco-ish bathrooms were really nice.  Complimetary jasmine scented shampoo, conditioner, bath wash and lotion bottles lined the counter.  I don't know how dudes deal with the jasmine scented stuff, but I liked it!   Our bed was very comfy but it was hard to sleep on the down pillows as I prefer the pillows to be firmer. 

MGM is home to Cirque du Soliel's KA show but as they were on "vacation", we couldn't get tickets.  There are several upscale restaurants and a Wolfgang Puck Cafe' on the main floor.  In the rear is a high-end Japanese restaurant, Emeril's restaurant, a Michael Mina seafood restaurant and 3 fast food places.  One for hot dogs, salads, the golden arches McD and an Italian\/pizza\/breakfast place.  Amble further down, you have a sandwich shop, CSI experience and a screening show.   
We didn't venture into the pool area which is another level lower, but I could see at least 2 pools but understand there's up to 5-6 pools and a gym somewhere.  What I like are the 2 Starbucks - one by the casino and one by the fast food places, both with long lines in the mornings.  

Take the escalator (by the front doors) downstairs to head to the garage and there are a few shops, ice cream, pretzels, a video shop where your head video is planted onto a dancing body (rather comic) and the popular footlong cocktails which is busy all day long.  There are 2 doors which exit right onto the Strip towards the back of the casino where there's a buffet, restaurant and Rainforest Cafe'.  They have a real lions' glass enclosure.  One day, we saw 2 adult females with their 3 trainers lying or sitting down next to them and on a 2nd day, there were 2 juveniles playing with their trainers.  Kinda sad to see these animals locked up.  I'd rather see the space used for more slots or restaurants insead of caged animals 'tho.

Nice rooms and awesome pool! Best pool I think and I've seen them all... good luck winning here though... never have and the "free drinks" hardly ever come around! Dropping hundreds  several times and didn't here "cocktails" even once

We stayed at the MGM for a conference with my company. I have stayed in Vegas over a dozen times, but never at the MGM. The room smelled like pot, you can't use the refrigerator without incurring a charge, there's no safe to keep your belongings, and worst of all--the front desk staff are rude and unhelpful. I was overcharged 3 separate times on my credit card, each time being told no one could see the charges I saw on my card. I spent over 3 hrs in person and on the phone trying to resolve these charges and I'm still fighting. I was also told my initial deposit of $250 would not be credited to my account. Despite a block rate of $160-190\/night, our bill for 4 nights was over $1200. You can stay at much nicer hotels on the strip for much less money with superior customer service. I will never stay here again and will continue to recommend that my friends do not either.

i love this hotel! the room is spacious with a big bathroom. i'm in love with the bed! it's super soft and filled with pillows. they even have a tub, which a lot of the hotels don't. 
they're room service was good. they came exactly at 9 for our breakfast and the food was great. 
the hotel itself was a big maze. one wrong turn and it can led u to a different part of the hotel. it can go for miles.

2 stars is for the bathroom the shower pressure was great and the mirror is awesome for putting makeup on. 
We stayed in the North rooms we booked a king room got 2 queens. The view feels like your in a basement it's off the second floor.. it was just really strange. 
The bed and the pillows were rough... bring your own pillow if you plan on staying here. We woke up with stiff necks. 
On our day of check out which was a Sunday I called to the front desk to see if we can extend our check out time and she said you can stay until 12. Which I was like awesome another hour of sleep. Then at 1130 we had a knock at our door from a lady with a clip board threatening us with a $500 fee because we were there past 11am. I made her aware the front desk had told me 12. She kept repeating herself that they don't allow 12 pm check out.. I told her she needs to speak with her front desk. 
My husband and I frequent all different hotels on a regular basis. And this is the first time I've experienced some one being this rude. This was our first and last time at MGM.

Big hotel big slow valet line. They apparently didn't have enough valets on duty? At least 200 people in line to check in. Not exaggerating I counted. Rooms are well appointed but we were upgraded, they're on the small side but you only need it to sleep right!? The hallway to the rooms are unbelievably long. Make sure you ask for a room  near the elevator. Sometimes bigger isn't better. The plus Frozen Fury is here so we didn't have to drive.

We liked staying at this hotel the room was nice not great for the price we paid. The staff was great and all the amenities wonderful. The room taxes in Vegas are kinda ridiculous but oh well... Overall I'd stay here again and I do recommend this place to stay.

oh damn. i need to update. i stayed here!!!! halloween 2010. it was quite the adventure. i loved seeing all the costumes. my fav by far was a dude straight dressed as french maid. awesomeness. i love the location. right across from ny ny. its pretty easy to get around from here. the rooms are a little dated but it gives u that old vegas feel. much different than ph. the buffet was the business and not too expensive. there is a lil mall there with a mcd's thats open 24 hour. perfect if you dont feel like stumbling down the strip to get ur mcnuggets on. the price of the room was decent especially being that it was a holiday. working in hotels myself i def understand the discount system. it seems to me that most people must be staying up from bellagio ( or aria?) it was only $99 a night. deal!!!!

Not my favorite Vegas hotel (I normally prefer the Aria), but I was here for a conference and it actually was better than I expected. 

Positives:
-- Rooms in the Grand tower have been renovated since the last time I stayed
-- Love the Whiskey Down bar in the casino (best place to play blackjack in a relaxed environment)
-- Lots of restaurants\/shops\/amenities close by
-- Service was actually really good, both at check-in, hotel operator, housecleaning, room service, restaurants
-- Pool area surprisingly good
-- Hakkasan
-- Great suites available for entertaining\/events

Negatives:
-- The crowd can be a bit sketchy.  There was a stabbing on the walkway to the hotel one night, and also I had to move my room the first day given a giant marijuana fest going on next door. To the hotel's credit, they moved my room immediately and were able to automatically change my keycard.
-- Gym is horrible -- way too small for such a large hotel
-- Conference facilities were cramped given the size of the conference
-- Conference food was average at best
-- At the end of the Strip

MGM is a 5k+ hotel complex on the south end of the Vegas Strip, near Aria, New York New York, Hooters, and Tropicana.  It is one of the nicer 4 star hotels in the lower price range and is part of a network of MGM corporate hotels in Vegas.  

MGM is large, but utilitarian in some respects.  Grand but some how compact. if you've never been to a Vegas hotel like Caesar's or Paris or Wynn or Venetian-- then you'll be very impressed here and with anything nearby it in comparison.  MGM was in many respects a high point in a line of hotels back in the 90s.  The hotel's thrill rides are gone today, but it's majesty remains, and low prices.

Pros-- 
a. Affordable, and sometimes very affordable
b. 3 nice large pools
c. lazy river (only weekends)
d. small mall inside
e. Quite a few entertainment and activities to purchase including KA, Jabba Woc Keez, David Copperfield, CSI, and more.  
f. Easy to purchase upgrade rooms at the front desk
g. Beautiful rooms, clean, and updated.
h. There's a great tram for $5 a trip or $10 a day that connects to the convention center.

Cons--
a. No microwaves in rooms, nor refrigerators and you can't get them either.
b. Rooms come with super expensive snacks w\/ $50 stocking fees and $5 soda's-- really bad if you have active kids. 
c.  You can feel lost or insignificant in the hotel, and you could be treated that way too.  
d.  There's no real feel that they are trying to make each guests experience great
e. There's a focus on up-selling at this hotel that is more than I've seen at other non-MGM hotels in Vegas. You can feel nickeled and dimed here. 
f. Because of the lazy river, there can be more families at this hotel.
*This is pretty much the same at all MGM resort properties. 

Tips: 
a. weekends are more money but have a lazy river open.   
b. Aria has a better buffet nearby that you can easily walk to
c.  Ka really is a great show and the best price will be in the hotel on the main floor at the box office. You will get cheaper and better seats this way no matter what the online site claims.

While this is a beautiful hotel, it's just not comparable and falls flat as a hotel, as a casino, and for it's location.  But that does make it cheaper than the others by about $50 to $100 per night. I recommend the others for more money as Vegas trips for many are once in a blue moon. While you can get the lazy river on weekends, the other hotels would be much closer in price on the north end of the strip and the experience would be far better.  Because of pricing you also have a different experience form the staff and other guests than on the north end.

BZ to our front dest agent who was very patient and kind to us.

While it's certainly a nice place to visit (food options are great from the cheap to the mid-range 24 hour Wolfgang Puck to the super pricey Robuchon), staying in the actual hotel was pretty awful. Super thin walls, a sad little bathroom and dirty looking sheets are not okay. 

The curse of the Vegas 4 star strikes again. The bell guy told me they were planning on renovating the entire hotel and I hope they do. MGM is classic Vegas and deserves more.

My daughter has stayed with MGM numerous times and has always spoken highly of their outstanding service, in addition to the comps and perks she's received.  The amiable StayWell Concierge, checked us in quickly and efficiently and gave us a room upgrade.  The StayWell rooms have special additions, including aromatherapy, an air purifier, and a terrific special mattress;  these rooms are smoke free.  The early bird breakfast buffet, (We had a 2 for 1 comp, which basically cost us $10. each.) was huge, as expected, with many delicious choices.  Their M Life rewards program is a plus and offers numerous advantages.  Parking is free and, in fact, gives free access to the garages at other M Life properties (Aria, Bellagio, etc.).  Loved the float down the Lazy River;  the tube was $20., but you do get to keep it.  We found the location on The Strip to be quite satisfactory.  A nice choice of restaurants -- Fiamma and Morimoto were excellent. The staff at the hotel was generally friendly and helpful.  I can find no negatives to our stay and would return to MGM in a NY minute!

TLDR: MGM doesn't guarantee the room type you book and is unwilling to make it right.

I booked a Skyline Marquee Suite over a month before my wife's 30th birthday. I was thrilled to have a space to entertain the 15 guests I had attending from the local area and also staying in other rooms at the MGM. We planned to have dinner in the large room (with its two living rooms, two bedrooms, and three bathrooms) before heading downstairs.

Upon arrival on 9\/17\/16 around 4PM, Ricky informed me that they weren't able to honor the room choice and would instead have to downgrade me to a City View Suite (a much smaller room) and a regular room down the hall from it. 

I couldn't have been more disappointed. All the planning I had put into the location was rendered pointless because MGM stuck me in a tiny suite that was a joke for the entertaining that I had planned. I didn't have enough places to sit and had to apologize to my guests.

I understand that issues are going to come up but I would have expected an upgrade to a nicer room or a full refund when MGM isn't able to honor my room booking -- especially when it's a $1k+ suite. Ricky said it was due to a "plumbing issue" but forgive my skepticism that this was code for "we decided to comp your room to a high-roller."

The downgrade was bad enough but I was particularly put off by Ricky implying that he was doing me a favor by finding me a room at all. He gave me some money back but was unwilling to provide a full refund on the room that MGM didn't have for me. I didn't have time to find another solution since our guests were already en route (and the check-in process took 45 min). I felt some comfort in that Ricky promised that there would be a door between the living room and the bedroom, but (surprise, surprise) there was no door. I went back downstairs to inform Ricky and still no refund.

I thought about booking elsewhere (I've always had perfect experiences at The Venetian) but I stuck with MGM because I loved this room.

My fault for expecting them to save it for me.

UPDATE: See MGM's response for further proof that MGM won't refund when they can't deliver. Not your fault but not their problem!

Crazy check in line.  They need to figure out something about that...and also they need to have a check in line and a check out line.  Their beds and beddings need to catch up to other hotels.  It wasn't soft or comfy at all.  Feather pillows aren't good if they're not top notch. All there rooms are too far down the hallways.   They need rooms to be closer to the center of the casino.  Our rooms were fine, but some of our friends was allllll the way down and takes like 5-10 minutes to walk too.  The bathroom was small and old.

well this was a combo trip my husbands 50th birthday and our 28th anniversary, I decided to pay more then other hotels to stay at the MGM grand because we were going to the UFC fight, we were given a room in the west wing, the halls had no air, the room was small with no view, nothing like opening the door to the room and being in the bathroom so much for privacy, there was no counter space in the bathroom, the air conditioner was right by the head of the bed nothing like cold air in your face all night, the parking garage was under construction i think they were painting lines so 3 floors had no parking, the escalators in the parking garage did not work, I could go on and on, really for the price I paid i was very disappointed, I dont think i will be staying there again,

Four stars for the hotel: our room was spacious, clean, and well-stocked, but very far from the elevator.

Two stars for the casino: too spread out, the ashtrays on the blackjack tables rarely got cleared.

Three stars for the pool: lots of chairs, well-signed, and a delightful place to eat called the Cabana Cafe.

Three stars for the restaurants: is it too much to ask to have more than one place to get some sit-down breakfast besides a $25 buffet or a Rainforest Cafe? Feh.

Free wi-fi is a nice touch, assuming you wouldn't rather use the gym.

I came here on the last day of my trip specifically to play poker. It was the worst decision of the weekend. Of all the casinos I could have gone to instead, I convinced myself that the MGM was the most practical choice, since I had played here before in years past and enjoyed it then. How wrong I was.
The poker lounge is no longer next to the sports book section. I'm assuming it was moved in an attempt to give it a more prominent identity and add character on to itself. Suffice to say they have failed miserably on both marks.
The lounge is poorly lit and there's a very depressing feel to it. The chairs are comfortable, but that's about as good as it gets.
After playing for about an hour, I found myself in a dispute with another player over the proper turns in action. The dealer did absolutely nothing to correct the situation, so I requested a floor manager to come help settle the problem. I stood up from my seat to wait for the floor manager to walk over and what happened next was the most unprofessional interaction I've ever had with someone at the management level. 
Two words into beginning to describe what was going on at my table I was rudely interrupted by the floor man who demanded me to "sit down." I responded with "Excuse me?", to which he again repeated "sit down." That was enough for me. I calmly gathered my chips and cashed out at the front booth of the room. That is where I met another poker lounge manager named Mark, who I believe was the floor man's boss. He did absolutely nothing to help quell the situation and seemed to reinforce his employee's complete and total lack of respect and professionalism towards a paying guest. 
I will never return to the MGM Grand to play poker. There are a bevy of options elsewhere in Vegas to play cards, so save yourself a terrible experience and avoid this poker area. Unless, of course, you enjoy being disrespected and treated as if you were a child.

I really didn't like MGM, but giving it 2 stars probably isn't doing it justice.  I actually booked a last minute stay for 1 night bc I wasn't happy with another hotel I was staying at via priceline.  I bid 95 on a 3.5 star south strip hotel on a sat night, which I expected to be tropicana, but I was pleasantly surprised to get MGM.  The pros: decent size, fairly nice room; free wifi; great casino.  Cons: old tv (though I guess people don't come to Vegas to watch tv), & a lot of drunk, young obnoxious guests, as evidenced by the bowls of potato chips strewn all over the hallway.  I wouldn't stay here again.  I checked into the signature the next day, which was much nicer.

My husband posted about our trip too but I also want to post my own review given this was my first Vegas trip...

So first time going to Vegas and we show up stand in line FOREVER! Seriously if it wasnt for the nice lobby with music videos playing I'd feel like I was at the DMV. After waiting at least 20+ minutes for just the 2 people checking in before us (yes only 2 people) we finally get to the counter to find out our reservations were cancelled for some unnamed reason. Wait, what? Why? Couldnt tell us why and of course nobody from the hotel called prior to just cancelling us... 

We ended up getting our reservation re-opened and moved to a closer room to our friends that were a floor above us. Which was fine since it was a nicer room than what we originally paid for. (Hence keeping a star for that) BUT I had to ask for it (aka play a little hardball), even though the woman at the desk said they dont do "upgrades for free" after getting our reservation cancelled and it being a birthday weekend she opted to help us out. So the delux king it was rather than a petite king. Cool, thanks... 

2nd star was for the decent room. It was a little dated but comfortable, nice large bathroom, comfy bed, decent view of the mountains... But thats about where it ended. I realize I was in Vegas and people are there to party... all night... But I couldnt believe that there was no hotel security or something of the like to keep people respectable in the hallways to the rooms. I'm sorry but when I am ready to sleep I dont appreciate people hooting and hollaring just outside our room, which pretty much sounded like they came right in our room to yell. The sound of people going to and from was actually pretty bad. Knowing I am a light sleeper and can get pretty grumpy when my sleep is interrupted I went to the over priced little store near the lobby\/elevators and purchased ear plugs. Those helped a lot and allowed me to get some decent sleep. I am very thankful that the little store carried them otherwise I'd not be doing very well. 

Ok lets talk about the pool area... Good Lord it was CROWDED! But with my group of people we stayed in the Lazy River and ended up having an awesome time despite there not being any chairs or place to sit near the pool itself. We did take over some tables by the food area and werent bothered by staff at all for leaving our stuff there so it was cool. I quickly learned that even though there were tons of people in a rather small area everyone got along. Normally big crowds and booze lead to stupidness but everyone was great, all there just to have a good time. So if you are hesitant to try the lazy river because of how many bodies are in it, try it anyway. It was a great way to spend 4 hours and beat the heat and humidity. 

Seriously our trip was full of high and low points... High point at check out was the gentlemen that checked us out was really nice and ended up comping us on a few things because of the hassel of what we went through with getting our $75 food credit that we got with our room with booking thru the hotel and for the random cancel... We appreciated him, but upon checking our credit card statement when we got home there are now some pending charges that we dont understand WHY they are there. When we called the hotel the lady that answered was incredibly rude to my husband and literally wouldnt let him finish a sentence to try and explain what we were seeing on our credit card statement. So we're opting to wait and see how those pending charges get handled and go from there... So beware when staying here. Make sure you check your statements after your stay...

Over all for the absolute hassel of staying at this place I probably wont be back unless we are with another group again. The Lazy River wasnt enough to make me want to spend my hard earned dollars here. *IF* I did come back I would most likely try the Signature instead. After reading their reviews it sounds more like what I'd appreciate in a room and they have their own check out staff that are probably less crowded. The place is huge and can get fairly confusing to try and get anywhere but after a few trips up and back we were finally able to get our bearings and navigate. 

Final thoughts... The MGM looks really nice, its a beautiful property but service leaves a lot to be desired and their rooms are needing the current renovation that they are doing. But, the construction thats happening (that we thankfully didnt hear unlike our friends that got woken up at 9am by jack hammering) I think they should close off many more floors so that when you roll into bed at 4am you dont get woken up at 9am. Its not like the MGM can't afford to do so... 

Next time I am in Vegas I plan on going elsewhere...

This hotel is very pretty and has many amenities. However, the beds are not that comfortable and the pillows are horrible (we just slept without pillows). My main complaint though is that right in the lobby they sell wine and champagne. I asked the saleswoman if there was a corkscrew in the room (pretty standard for most hotel rooms anywhere) and she said "yes or they can bring you one up". We get upstairs with our bottle of wine and there is no corkscrew in the room. We call down and they said "its gonna take an hour and there's a 6 fee" (to borrow it.) Really? It is LAS VEGAS and you dont provide your guests with corkscrews?? We bought a shitty one for $20

I stated in an executive king suite which was fun for a weeknight price. I was excited about the pool, but it was underwhelming. I did not regret staying here once, but would probably stay at aria or Cosmo next time.
One gripe I have about all Vegas rooms I have seen is that the mini bar takes up the entire fridge so you cannot cool the drinks you bought on the cheap at CVS.

Ok we've come to terms (or not) with paying for parking, but 30 minutes in line to leave the car so we can eat at Craft Steak is not acceptable. Sure, it's a busy time for the valet (7 pm EDC weekend), but it's not as if they didn't expect a crowd: staff accordingly. And the parking staff are clearly upset at what has happened to their income.

We got so lucky when we went.  I booked this hotel through Costco Travel and got the best deal.  We got to stay when one of their wings was first remodeled and we got to stay in new rooms for the same price as the others because of a Costco deal.  The night we arrived there was a UFC fight by chance and I got to see Chuck Liddell (whom I love) and Randy Couture.  It was a good place to stay at for my first Vegas trip.  Studio 54 was cool too.  I enjoyed it and would defs go back.

If you visit this Hotel be prepared to hassle with getting into your room and parking with these card keys. A huge frustration waiting to find someone to get you in your room or trying to get in or out of parking. It actually happened several times. They were nice enough to give us some credit but walking around all day and wanting to get back to your room for rest was just plain not a smooth transition unfortunately.

Staying here now. Upon checkin we were told they were so booked so we got an upgrade.... upgrade to a room with no hot water, no view, and no water pressure.  We're only staying here one night, thank goodness because it will also be the last.


Edit.
There's more:
The sheets smelled terrible
The pillows were awful
I spent my morning listening to the person next door throwing up. Walls were that thin.
Speakers sucked.

WORST. I can't even give them 0 star. Their site charged me twice because of some error and when I got there to check in- instead of fixing everything or transferring the charge to just one room (they already took more than the deposit) they tried to charge me again! So I cancelled, but then they still took the deposit(s) out of my account... I definitely will not be back-- never had an issue like this with any other hotel EVER.

I should have read my own review of this hotel before booking a room. 

Unless you are paying a much lower rate, I would avoid the West Wing entirely. It's small, dark, and kind of smells. There's also no separation between the bedroom and the bathroom, so unless you are alone, you aren't going to have any privacy when you're on the dumper (there's just a glass door). And if you happen to be placed on the casino-level floor, as I was, you are going to be subjected to every loud, drunken idiot who passes by your door.

MGM might have the finest poker room ever with the most charismatic dealers and the best Manager in the business(Mr.Boyd). But, they got a real problem at the rest of the casino and hotel. 

Last year reservations made a crucial mistake that cost me about $100. I made a reservation for a Saturday, and even told the agent that I wanted the room for SATURDAY and she confirmed the numerical date as well. When I arrived on Saturday, they had no reservation for me. The front desk agent who had a thick Eastern European accent was in a rotten mood due to the guests who she serviced before me being very out-of-line and difficult. She was still steaming when I got to her and she had abandoned all of her customer service and hospitality skills. Eventually, she had found out that the reservation agent had made my reservation for Friday. I insisted that it was mistake and she shouts: "WHY ARE YOU PEOPLE DOING THIS TO ME TODAY?". I could have interpreted the "you people"  remark as a racist remark, but didn't know if that comment was due to the fact that English didn't appear to be her first language. Eventually she told me that she was not going to charge me for a no-show on Friday and that she could check me in. That turned out to be a complete lie. I didn't catch it until recently, but I was looking though some bank statements and noticed that she in fact did charge me as a no-show. 

The casino floor is not that much better. I played blackjack for 4-6 hours a day, betting about $50 a hand for about two weeks in a row here, and my rewards card still has a comp balance of $0.00. I believe that this is one of those casinos where they do that Vegas style "age discrimination". Many Vegas casinos do not like to comp young people who are in their 20s, no matter how big they bet. They like to comp the geriatrics and seniors even though they may only play penny slots. There is no real rational reason why they do this but remember that since the corporations took over Vegas, they have been losing revenue due to their marketing department being full of unqualified pretty girls and trust fund babies whose Dad's had connections to get them in. 

I still would like to point out that the people who work at the gift shops are very nice and polite, and the dealers are all very qualified to work at such an upscale establishment. But, next time I have guests in town who I want to impress, I will absolutely never check them in at the MGM.

Drinks $16 (16 oz. cups full of ice);  ATM $12.50 service fee per $100 withdrawal.  Ask to stay in the central tower,  otherwise you have to walk about 1000 feet to the elevators.   The restaurants are outrageously priced - go out on the strip to eat and drink- you'll find fairly priced restaurants.

It's located right before the strip starts in Vegas.  It's not as hip as the newer hotels, but it's still got that partying vibe going on.  The customer service was fantastic when we stayed here.  They were on top of things with the room being clean and making sure you are happy with everything.  Besides, how often do you go to a hotel that has a real lion habitat?  If you're lucky, you might be able to take some up close photos of the lions if you can squeeze through the crowd.  The two times that I passed by the habitat has always been packed, so be prepared.  The hotel also gives out free coupons for the buffet (buy one, get one free) and discounts for shops in the hotel.  Also, if you have time, check out Studio 54.  This nightclub is insane.  It consists of 4 floors with bars on each one with latest music you can dance to.  The lines to get into this place are long, so it might be a wise idea to get there early to avoid the wait.  And the pools!  It was so nice to go for a tube ride around the lazy river.  The hotel has 5 standard pools and 3 jacuzzis.  It's hard to pick one, so we went in all 8!  ;)

Smoky & over crowded is the only was to explain this place

We were just walking around looking for somehig to do since coyote ugly across the street was a bust

The zoo habitat there or whatever was a total snooze fest not to mention not any  animals in sight
All I kept hearing as people walked past was where are the lions & by the looks of the casino the animals were probably just as bored as we were

Ok casino I guess if your rolling with a family but I wasnt so it was time to go & fast

WORST EXPERIENCE EVER. I reserved a pent house suite, WAS NOT A PENTHOUSE- had no comps or anything for over 3k in gambling, Had NO HOT WATER for 2 days, being fixed the last night @4am. Was told we could reserve sunday night, then called at 2pm and said we had to evacuate because it had been rented to someone else and then charged my card for a full night and another $200 for whatever reason. Amongst all that, ordered 70$ worth of food from Wolf gang pucks and waited 45 minutes for a half chicken (which another person ordered after me and received theirs first), was a pile of skin and bones. IT WAS DISGUSTING And it made my husband sick. Now I have to wait a week for my money to return. Then they send me to the ARIA where they charged my card (which was supposed to be a comp) another $248.55, and put me in a disgusting handi-cap room which smelt horrible and had trash and bags and PILLS all over the bed.. This was my 3 year anniversary. RUINED. Worst vegas trip of my entire life.

This review of MGM Grand is like so many other experiences in Vegas -- first you're up, then you're down, then you're even, and if you're smart, you get the heck out of there to live to play another day -- you know you'll be back.

We usually prefer to stay at Mirage, for the central-Strip location and the familiarity -- there's no need to get reoriented on every trip. However, the group we were traveling to meet in mid-November had planned to stay at MGM  (way down on the south side of the Strip). It's in the Mirage group, so at least our points would still add up (gotta earn that free buffet, yo!). So we booked our MGM reservation and looked forward to hanging out with some friends while exploring a new scene. Alas, there was a last minute change of plans and somehow we wound up being the only couple in the group staying at MGM and I was NOT going to spend $200 to change our hotel booking via Southwest Vacations (Note to self: splurge on the trip insurance whenever traveling with a fickle large group).

Big plus: 
You can check-in at the airport and walk straight to your room, key-in-hand. I loved breezing past the masses waiting at the hotel desk.

We had reserved a West Wing mini-suite, and it was at the end of the longest hallway on earth, 5th floor. I'm pretty sure I walked about 25 miles every time I left the room to go to the casino or anywhere else. Lord, don't these architects know that women are wearing some very high heels in this town (strictly for looking hawt while sitting or standing still, possibly for limited dancing) and we do NOT want to trudge around for hours in them?  Big plus: the hallways upstairs are very cushion-y, so off went my shoes each time I exited the elevator... squish, squish, squish, ahhhh, better.

The room, the good: 
We loved the super clean & comfy bed and modern decor, including the fun TV built into the bath vanity mirror. There's no tub, but there is a huge shower with body jets. Lots of floor-to-ceiling mirrors in the corners of the bedroom make the space appear much larger than it is.
